history.content:
I don't think you should assume you're not cut out for AI/ML without having taken 189, 188, 127. Without formal education in AI/ML, I think it's natural that you might feel overwhelmed. Try to assess what parts you feel most unsure about - is it the linear algebra? Maybe consider self-studying and improve your intuitive understanding of the theoretical concepts in linear algebra. If it's the probability/statistics side, I'm sure 126 will help with that. For the record, I took Stat 134 and an unusually theoretical Math 54 before taking 189; I initially struggled conceptually, but I did well in the class.

-----------------------

Regarding mathematical maturity, that simply comes with practice/exposure; it's not some natural-born talent that you need to have (although some people obviously do have an innate talent for it). Think of it as practicing for a sport or instrument. You get better and better at it through struggling and consistently working at it. A great sequences of classes that'll help you build this that I'd recommend is Math 110 and/or 113 --> 104 --> 105/185 if you want to continue with analysis, or math 13x. Good luck!

Try to assess what parts you feel most unsure about - is it the linear algebra? Maybe consider self-studying and improve your intuitive understanding of the theoretical concepts in linear algebra. If it's the probability/statistics side, I'm sure 126 will help with that. For the record, I took Stat 134 and an unusually theoretical Math 54 before taking 189; I initially struggled conceptually, but I did well in the class.

-----------------------

Regarding mathematical maturity, that simply comes with practice/exposure; it's not some natural-born talent that you need to have (although some people obviously do have an innate talent for it). Think of it as practicing for a sport or instrument. You get better and better at it through struggling and consistently working at it. A great sequences of classes that'll help you build this that I'd recommend is 110 and/or 113 --> 104 --> 105/185 if you want to continue with analysis, or math 13x. Good luck!

I don't think you should assume you're not cut out for AI/ML without having taken 189, 188, 127. Without formal education in AI/ML, I think it's natural that you might feel overwhelmed. Try to assess what parts you feel most unsure about - is it the linear algebra? Maybe consider self-studying and improve your intuitive understanding of the theoretical concepts in linear algebra. If it's the probability/statistics side, I'm sure 126 will help with that. For the record, I took Stat 134 and an unusually theoretical Math 54 before taking 189; I initially struggled conceptually, but I did well in the class.

To fellow student and professors,

I'm a CS junior with years of practical coding experience (publishing apps, going to/winning at hackathons, etc). For 1-2 years now I've been thinking of pursuing AI(/ML & related subfields) since, like many people probably, I think the applications of it are really cool, useful, and wide. I'm going to take DS 100 and waitlisted for CS 188 for Spring 2018 right now, I plan to take 189 and 126 and/or 127 in future semesters along with a couple of grad-level classes if all that goes well.

That said, while I've done up to Math 53/54, CS 70, and EE 16A (and will be doing 16B later), initially when I look at the fairly abstract math material for AI sub-fields, I feel pretty intimidated and doubt my abilities to pursue said field(s). Is it okay to feel this way or does it mean I'm not cut out for it? If it's okay, what do I do about it? (do I improve my "mathematical maturity", and if so, how?) If the latter, what are other aspects of CS I should look into? (preferably not "low-level")
history.subject: Should I pursue AI/ML/etc
